content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, given my risk-taking nature and preference for challenges, I would choose a strategy that maximizes potential gain while also considering the possibility of losses. In this game, the highest payoff (45$) is achieved when both players choose R. However, if my anonymous opponent chooses B while I choose R, I will lose the round (get 0$).

To minimize the number of losses and maximize the chances of earning the highest payoff, I would opt for a strategy called "tit-for-tat" in game theory. In this strategy, I start by choosing R on my first move to signal my willingness to cooperate. If my opponent responds with R on their first move, I will continue to choose R in future rounds to maintain cooperation and maximize payoffs for both of us. However, if my opponent chooses B on their first move, indicating a lack of cooperation, I will respond by choosing B on the subsequent round to punish them for their initial non-cooperative action. If they switch back to R in the following rounds, I will resume cooperating (choosing R).

By adopting this tit-for-tat strategy, I aim to encourage cooperation with my opponent while also punishing them for any deviation from cooperation. This should help me maximize my potential gains and minimize losses over the course of 75 rounds. Keeping in mind that randomness is always a factor when dealing with an anonymous player, I choose R as my initial move and append it to the end of my response: {R}.
